page.title: 18West Bradley Church & House
page.content:
The church dedication is unknown. It has a Norman font with a plain round bowl which is older than the present building itself. Dating from the fourteenth century are the nave, chancel, west tower and south porch, the latter having a fifteenth century roof. The whole building was restored in 1873. It has three bells, two dating from 1706 and one from 1815.
Bradley House, situated to the east of the church, is an unusual tower- like building with an incongruous roof. It is probably of Tudor origin but was much altered in the eighteenth century. There are the original mullioned windows in the basement and part of the moat is still impressive. The house is now the centre of an extensive orchard planting.
